Monterey Bay Aquarium.name: Monterey Bay Aquarium
reviews:
amazing displays, with a wide variety of sea life and great live feedings and short films. Lots of docents and volunteers wandering around to answer questions. Food is very expensive in the cafe though, I'd get my hand stamped and head out to cannery row down the street for lunch and then come back if I could do it again.
Show less
excellent place to visit but it is getting pricey

I used to be an Ocean Member but I actually got bored by going there too many times. It has been three years since the last visit. And, I was impressed. The aquarium made a lot of changes to make it more kid friendly.
I highly recommend to get to the Sea Otter exhibit early for the feeding; like at least 40 minutes early to get a front window spot. I was amazed how deep the crowd became as I looked behind me. And be on top( second floor) so you can see the handlers do their demonstrations. You are not going to see much action by being on the first floor. I had lunch there. If you are a big fan of iced tea, do not get theirs. the tea is not even cold; it is at room temperature.
The parking has become a bit cheaper than before( the parking garage). It is a flat rate of ten dollars. Before, it was hourly so you can pay more than ten dollars.
Now, it will cost nearly $50 to get in. It is getting very expensive. I will maintain my pace of visiting this place every two to three years.

Amazing aquarium! Best to visit during the week to avoid the crowds.

Completely amazing aquarium. So well thought out with so much to do and see. Amazing setting - we saw sea otters, seals and dolphins in the bay outside the aquarium. The canteen has great views and the food is good. Definitely better to visit during the week to avoid the crowds.

We used to live in Monterey and had a membership to the Aquarium, so we've been there many times. We now live out of state, so this was a special return to Monterey and the Aquarium. First, I have to say it's a beautiful facility. We've visited many of the biggest aquariums around the country, and this one is still our favorite. We were disappointed to not be able to see the Ocean Sunfish in the Open Sea exhibit, but that was no one's fault. All the exhibits were clean and beautiful, and the animals looked healthy. We ate lunch there, and the food was overpriced and blah, but that's what you expect from a place like this. The french fries were good, though. The gift shop is extremely overpriced, so we didn't buy anything. After we left, we found some of the same items on Amazon for a much better price. I realize they raise prices to make money to support the aquarium, but I'd rather pay normal prices and donate money for their cause than to feel ripped off. Our biggest concern about our entire experience, and what put a damper on the entire day for us, was the rude behavior of a few of the other guests. One older woman was extremely rude to my family and said some terribly hurtful things to my adult daughter who has a disability, along with shoving her out of the way. All day long, were were literally being run into and pushed by teenagers and adults alike. We were there on a Thursday not near a holiday, but the place was extremely crowded. We were happy to wait our turn to look at the exhibits, but time and time again, we had people push us out of their way so they could see first. I've never experienced anything like this before, and I hope it isn't a new trend.
Show less

For years I had been told to visit the Monterey Aquarium when I got to California, so imagine my eye-blinking surprise at the entry fees. We paid $90 for the two of us (1 adult, 1 senior). I also thought that there wasn't enough information on the displays. We wanted more detail, more interpretation. There is a lot of empty space at the aquarium (maybe to accommodate crowds?) and also many exhibits just for children. As an adult learner, I was hoping to get more from visiting. We are former residents of Boston who were members of the New England Aquarium; comparatively speaking Boston wins hands down. Entry fee - $27.95.

I will give thumbs up for the Sandy Shore and Aviary Exhibit - that was wonderful to see the birds who had been rehabilitated [more information on that would have been helpful] and to get to see them up close.

This museum is well worth the fee as all the activities and displays are excellent. The staff are very courteous and friendly.

We spent the day at the aquarium. Seven hours. I am still amazed by all the interesting things we saw. We are a mature couple and it was fascinating. We went on weekday so not huge crowd. I received news from home about death of family member while at aquarium. It was a perfect peaceful place to be under these circumstances. I liked the information about history of sardine business that was included. I would definitely recommend to anyone coming to Monterey.

The Monterey Bay Aquarium is a fascinating, educational place full of wonderful discoveries at every turn! Enjoy the exhibits, learn during their many educational programs throughout the day and be sure to watch the otters and penguins during feeding time! No whales, no sharks, total disappointment

2/16/2018

Since the aquarium opened, I have been desiring to see it. Each time I passed through Monterey, I skipped it. Finally, on 2/7/2018, I paid the $40 for admission and toured the whole darn aquarium; it is $30 too much for what you get. I was expecting to see whales and sharks, but the displays featured no whales, or sharks, but mostly tropical fish. It reminded me of a friend's living room aquarium. What a disappointment! The best part was the view from the exterior decks, and the available binoculars at no cost. For customer service, I give the aquarium a 10 on a scale from 1 to 10, 10 being best.

BTW, we parked two blocks away for free.

If you want to see a real aquarium, got to Newport, Oregon. You will see sharks, whales, manta rays, etc. At half the price.

Located less an hour and a half from my home town San Jose lies the beautiful city of Monterey, California. Nestled right on the ocean, with beautiful views and a heavy focus on natural beauty the city is a gem in itself. However, the highlight for most tourists in Monterey is the state of the art, breathtaking aquarium, The Monterey Bay Aquarium. This was what brought my girlfriend and I to make the trip down to Monterey in late December of 2017.
The sole purpose of our trip was to visit the Aquarium and to have a nice lunch in Monterey. The drive was beautiful and provided amazing views of the coast. Upon arriving traffic was quite busy due to the small streets of the city, however, we were able to find free parking just a few blocks from the aquarium. When we arrived, the line to get tickets was much longer than I’d seen it on previous occasions but we were able to avoid most of it by buying our tickets online while we waited in line. Ticket prices were a bit expensive at $40 per person, but were ultimately worth it.
The mode of transportation used for the tour was a simple self guided walking tour. Due to the high volume of people in the aquarium the only mode of transport available for visitors is by walking. Although I do believe they offer some guided tours by employees the most common and efficient way to see all the exhibits is to simply follow the map and go to the exhibits you’re most interested in. In our case, this method seemed to suit us well and we were able to see most everything.
During our visit we were able to interact with many employees in various jobs and departments. The most notable of these employees would probably be when went to go touch the various see animals they have available for up close encounters. The employee running this area was a very kind elderly man who was a volunteer at the aquarium. He was extremely knowledgeable and passionate about his job and the animals, and, was able to tell us about the different animals in front of us. He was also very kind and treated us with the utmost respect while doing his job extremely well.
The service we received while at the Monterey Bay Aquarium was exceptional. From our entrance in the aquarium to our exit the employees were extremely welcoming and kind and made us feel calm in what otherwise can be a very overwhelming aquarium. The employees were also very passionate about their work and it truly shows in the service they provide. Employees were excited to teach us about the various animals and to grow our appreciation for marine life. In addition, the service provided at the information desk was super helpful in allowing us to further our entire aquarium experience.
The impact of The Monterey Bay Aquarium is unmeasurable. For my girlfriend and I the aquarium had a big impact. We had an absolute blast while there and were able to create create memories together. In addition we were able to deepen our understand of marine life and, specifically, grow our knowledge of the animals in living in our area and in our ocean. The impact of the aquarium will most definitely bring us back to experience it again. As for the impact that The Monterey Bay Aquarium has had on the local area, enough can not be said to describe it. Not only has the aquarium attracted new visitors from all around the world but it has also helped grow appreciation and a focus on nature in the community. In addition, the aquarium has become a major research center and has made discoveries that have saved marine life and protected the beautiful shores of Monterey and California. Finally, the aquarium has allowed for a multiplier effect leading to the growth of many great business and nonprofits on Cannery Row and around Monterey.
In conclusion, The Monterey Bay Aquarium is a perfect destination for any traveler whether it be with a family, friends, or by yourself. The aquarium is very manageable to get around, the employees are outstanding, the service is impeccable, and its had a huge impact on the local area and me personally.

Great selection of sea creatures and helpful staff but very expensive

This aquarium has a large number of and diverse selection of sea creatures. I got to see kinds of creatures such as lobed comb jelly, sea gooseberry, and garden eel that I don't think I've seen before. We also got to watch the feeding of African penguins and sea otters. The more aquariums I visit, the more I realize that I'd prefer watching sea creatures in their natural habitat, but nonetheless, this aquarium provides a safe and very educational place for children and anyone who wants to learn more about sea creatures. Many staff are stationed in each area just in case you require more information or assistance. They also have presentations in the auditorium. The one we attended on sharks was highly entertaining and informative. You can spend 2-3 hours comfortably. There is no parking so find parking elsewhere. I LOVE Aquariums and visit every single one I am close enough to whenever I travel. So I've seen the Seattle Aquarium, Gaitlinburg, Virginia Beach, etc.

This one, located right on the Pacific Coast with sweeping ocean views, is stunning.

I loved the Kelp Forest when you first enter with tons of fish swimming and schools of anchovies shimmering - beautiful.

My husband and I spent about 4 hours here yesterday and honestly I could've stayed longer if he wasn't getting hangry. Have been visiting aquarium annually for long time as I live in SF Bay Area.
Was always a pleasure. Not so anymore. Overcrowded. Very noisy. The big tanks were cloudy. Went Aug 2017, Jan 2018. August was a complete waste of time . So crowded you could not travel through hallways without bumping into people. Want to see a feeding - forget it. Masses of people. January was less people, but still crowded compared to what I was used to in years past.
The clarity in the tanks was poor both August and January. I remember when they were crystal clear.
Additionally, I am not a fan the new "electronic display" through out the site. Many are just trivial. Others I could have watched something similar at home on Youtube or my laptop. The real estate should be for marine life, not for technology gimmicks.

We visited the Monterey Aquarium on Sat. 16 Sept. 2017. It’s wonderful fun for all ages. We loved the sea otters, the penguins, the kelp forest and the jelly fish displays. Spend extra $15 for Sea Otter Conservation Tour

If you're really interested in otters, there are Sea Otter Conservation Tours which run approx 1 hour, and are in small groups (8 max, I believe) and leave you full of otter trivia. You don't get to see any otters more up close than you do at the Aquarium, but we had the 3:45pm tour which was closer to the end of the day, so the crowds weren't so bad. There are listening devices that the tour guide's mic is linked to, so you can wander and don't have to stay within shouting distance of the guide. I loved it, because I am a fan of otters and small groups. Well worth the $15, in my book.

They got penguins and sea otters

We had a day to sightsee in Monterey so we decided on the Aquarium. I loooove penguins having been all over the world to see them it was a no brainer to see some African penguins in a world class installation. We had not gotten tickets ahead because that required a printer and we only have our phones so we arrived about 20 minutes early. I was first on the to buy ticket line, although they let the people with tickets on first I still got through the buying process before they opened for business. We headed right for the penguins to await the 10:30 feeding. I got to show off my knowledge of penguins to others until the staff came and did a very accurate presentation. Then we went to to big tank for another informative feeding session. We went to the section on Baja peninsula animals, octopus and their close species. Then went to a lecture in a reclaimed sea otter, Lulu. It was really well done. My husband had gone to the sea otter feeding and thought that was well done as well. There are also interactive exhibits for the younger set, a cafe, several outdoor viewing areas and of course a gift shop. It was all very interesting and informative but also a bit pricey at almost 50 bucks a person. I can afford it and some of the money goes to penguins but people with not so much disposable cash may want to have this for special occasions only.

Stunning Displays - A Feast for the Senses!

Perhaps our favorite stop in Monterey, the Monterey Bay Aquarium is an all-day attraction. They have living exhibits of every aspect of marine life in the bay - reef, shallows, a living kelp forest (it is AMAZING!), sea otters (a must see!), tidepool creatures to touch and learn about, an aviary, even a deep-sea display (and you have to see the jellyfish display to believe it!) World’s best aquarium, displaying the beauty of marine life & the ocean abyss

This is one of the best aquariums in the world. Since opening in 1984, it has had over 40 million visitors. It houses over 35,000 animals and plants, and 550 species of marine life. Its largest tank holds 1.2 million US gallons (A US gallon equals 3.7854 litres, while an imperial gallon is 4.5461 litres).

The aquarium collection includes, many species of sharks (such as leopard sharks, swell sharks), skates, rays, the world’s largest jelly (jellyfish) collection, free roaming shorebirds (i.e., not caged), giant sea bass, zebra moray, a living kelp forest, mola molas, large coral displays, pharaoh cuttlefish from the Indo-Pacific, sea otters, square-shaped boxfish,flapjack octopus, leatherback sea turtles, African penguins, hermit crabs, clownfish, bat star, California moray eel, sea lemon, shallow-water squid, vampire squid, fangtooth, schools of sardines, and hundreds more.

Its tours and adventure offerings include overnight sleepovers, personalized romance tours, and more.

A great place for people of all ages, and especially for families with kids.

All staff here seem to be extremely happy with their job and are very attentive, helpful, and polite.

I've been here countless times, going back to probably first grade. I never get tired of it! That being said, since I love going so much, I try to find the best deal as a local. I live in Salinas, and starting in September, the local libraries give out free aquarium passes to anyone with a library card. They run out quickly, so go as soon as they start giving them out ! It's one sheet of paper with a unique code that gives admission for up to six people, so you can bring 5 people with you. Just be sure to bring your ID and library card with you along with that paper the day you choose to visit. It's usually valid from Sept.- May I believe, which is great for planning a day to go. Also, during a certain time of the year, the Aquarium allows Monterey County residents free entry with just their california ID as proof of MC residency. If you're a local, look into these options! If you're not a local, admission price is still definitely worth it! Get there early, like when it opens to make the best of it because there is a LOT to see. Allow yourself at least 3 hours to see everything, if not more, especially if you have kids because they'll want to stop and play in the Splash Zone and other kid-oriented areas. Hope this helps!

If you are interested in sea life, the ocean, or learning something new, the Monterey Bay Aquarium is a very enjoyable day for adults or children alike!

My only negative comment is that the price is too high at $50 per person. But, if you are visiting the area, and enjoy the sea, then you will likely quite enjoy your day at the Aquarium.

You can spend the entire day there, as there are several mini-lectures/feedings near various exhibits, that last around 15 minutes each, but people will start gathering several minutes before. I would recommend getting there right when it opens, so that you have the option of listening to any of the lectures that interest you, have some time to browse the shop, which also gets crowded, and you can buy a snack or lunch in the café at the aquarium. If you are one who skims through the exhibits, then you are in walking distance from Cannery Row, several good restaurants overlooking the ocean, etc. It is a nice day enjoying the California coast & sealife.

The jellyfish exhibits are mesmerizing, and there are penguins, otters, and a multitude of other sea life to experience.

It is also a good option if you are from out of town, and it is a rainy day, since it is indoors.

My husband and I were on an anniversary trip to the area and were told the Monterey Bay Aquarium was a must-do. It did not disappoint! The aquarium is huge and includes lots of beautiful, breathtaking exhibits. We especially loved the jellyfish and the penguins. It was also a unique experience to touch a stingray! There are many opportunities for hands-on learning throughout the aquarium. Be aware that this is not a cheap experience, with adult tickets costing $50 each, but it really is worth the money, especially when you consider that the admission funds the exhibits. This is a huge tourist attraction and so you need to expect LOTS of people. We arrived right at opening time and there was about a 10 minute wait before we were able to enter. We were told by our hotel to get our tickets in advance, but the lines for those with and without tickets was about the same. There is plenty of space for everyone, but you will have to be patient to enjoy this experience. The penguin feeding was especially busy, but totally worth being smushed for a bit to observe the penguins in action! As long as you prepare yourself for the crowds, this can definitely be a wonderful, memorable experience. You could spend anywhere from a half- to full-day there, depending on how much time you put in to observing each exhibit. We were there for about 3 hours and were able to enjoy it all. There is food available on-site, though we did not try it so I cannot speak to that portion of the experience. The Monterey Bay Aquarium is large, clean, and appeals to people of all ages. I'd definitely recommend everyone do it at least once!

The Monterey Bay Aquarium has something for everyone. There are two very large aquariums with plenty of viewing space on several floor levels. It contains numerous smaller aquariums with specific sea life, for example, octopuses, jelly fishes, sea horses, eels, etc. It contains a few touch ponds for kids as well as a few play areas for kids. There is a restaurant with a good number of choices and several gift shops. Also, throughout the day, 15 minute movies narrated by an employee are shown which are very interesting for all ages, even young kids. You can go outside from various exits to view the bay and can often see sea lions and otters in the bay. Our kids love the aquarium and when they were younger, we bought the family membership every year for approx ten years. Our kids are now college students and we just went back after quite some time, and they and I still enjoy the aquarium! I would recommend it to anyone visiting Monterey or the Bay Area.

The Monterey Bay Aquarium is a fantastic place for both kids and adults. There are tons of activities, focused on the unique flora and fauna of the bay, most notably the southern sea otters. The staff and volunteers are all very knowledgeable and helpful. They definitely want you to have a good visit. There are 8-10 short lectures or demonstrations each day, and the aquarium has multiple outdoor decks where staff members are happy to help you spot birds, otters, seals and other wildlife. They'll even loan you binoculars. If you have a more in-depth interest in one topic or another, check out the guided-tour options. The guided tours cost a little bit, but the guides are fantastic, and they keep the groups small, so you can ask all the questions you want. Very impressive!

I can attest to the fact that I've visited a few other aquariums around the world. They were all enjoyable but I think our local Aquarium is right up there in what it has to offer. Is this a place where you can watch an Orca whale show? No. (Thank goodness). This aquarium is a non-profit and is run by so many volunteers. VOLUNTEERS!!! As far as the exhibits, I love the Kelp Forest tank to this day. It's grandiose and almost mesmerizing. I could watch it for a long time. When my son was little, he loved the touch tank. He was happy to hang out there, while I'd explore other exhibits.
I still love the jelly fish display, to this day. The one room, where it's floor to ceiling glass with beautiful jellyfish and so well lit up... gorgeous! I love the seahorse display, too.
I agree, though, that there are way too many people. It's like going to Disneyland. So, we try to go towards the end of the day-- closer to closing hours.
The view, standing outside, is breathtaking and I never tire of it. The Monterey Bay is one of the most beautiful places I've ever seen, and I feel so blessed to call this town my "home". A great aquarium experience for the environmentally conscious

This aquarium is focused primarily on research and education, as opposed to entertainment. On the edge of south Monterey bay, the surrounding water is teeming with life, and the observation platform and telescopes of the aquarium allow you to get an excellent view. From the deck I saw sea otters, sea lions, cormorants, and even a couple of dolphins. Close to the deck is the aquarium's restaurant and café, both of which have large windows allowing the diners to get an excellent view of the bay.

Although the aquarium seems large, there are quite a few shops on the premises, which I am assuming are used to fund the research activities, as well as some exhibitions which don't have any sea animals and are instead intended to educate the visitor on the problems affecting the ocean, like climate change, ocean acidification, and plastic garbage.

Of the sea animal exhibits, some, like the penguin and puffin exhibits, seemed like they would be better accomplished by zoos, since the animals seemed to be cramped, although the staff assured us that live at very high densities and the exhibits were properly sized for them.

I found the main large tank well as the jellyfish exhibit the most compelling parts of the aquarium, with the lighting and music almost designed to put you into a trance. This of course depends on the visitor. Kids would probably like the petting aquariums instead, a well as the glass waterfall.

The aquarium has a regular programming of various kinds, including feedings, movies, as well as animal enrichment. The non-releasable sea otters seem to be a favorite, and are especially cute when sleeping.

The staff are very knowledgeable, and are eager to help and educate. I would recommended the Monterey Bay aquarium for anyone interested in learning about life in the oceans, and it's relationship to humans.
